{{Infobox software | name = Taskwarrior | title = | logo = Taskwarrior logo.png<!-- Image name is enough --> | screenshot = Taskwarrior screenshot.png<!-- Image name is enough --> | caption = Taskwarrior 1.9.x demonstrating colored themes. | author = Paul Beckingham | developer = Paul Beckingham, Federico Hernandez, David J Patrick, John Florian, Cory Donnelly, Johannes Schlatow, Dirk Deimeke, Scott Kostyshak, Renato Alves, Wim Schuermann, Tomas Babej | released = {{Start date and age|2008|06|03|df=yes}} | discontinued = | latest release version = 2.5.1 | latest release date = {{Start date and age|2016|02|24|df=yes}} | latest preview version = | latest preview date = <!-- {{Start date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|df=yes}} --> | status = Active | programming language = [[C++]]<ref>[https://git.tasktools.org/projects/TM/repos/task/browse Taskwarrior Git Repository]</ref> | operating system = [[Windows]] (Cygwin), [[Linux]], [[Mac OS X]], [[BSD]] | platform = | size = | language = English | language count = <!-- Number only --> | language footnote = | genre = [[Task management]], [[Time management]] | license = [[MIT License]] | website = {{URL|https://taskwarrior.org}} }} '''Taskwarrior''' is an open-source, cross platform [[Time management|time]] and [[task management]] tool. It has a [[command-line interface]] rather than a [[graphical user interface]].
Taskwarrior uses concepts and techniques described in ''[[Getting Things Done]]'' by [[David Allen (author)|David Allen]], but is paradigm-agnostic in that it does not require users to adhere to any given life-management philosophy.<ref>https://taskwarrior.org/docs/start.html</ref>
According to its author, Taskwarrior was created "to address layout and feature issues"<ref>[http://taskwarrior.org/wiki/taskwarrior/About About Taskwarrior], {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100408100712/http://taskwarrior.org/wiki/taskwarrior/About |date=April 8, 2010 }}</ref> in the Todo.txt applications popularized by [[Gina Trapani]].<ref>[http://todotxt.com/ Todo.txt] Future-proof task tracking in a file you control</ref>
With ''Timewarrior,'' the authors offer an accompanying tool to track time spent on projects.<ref>http://taskwarrior.org/news/news.20160620.html</ref> Configuration allows e. g. to define recurring breaks such as lunch time.<ref>http://taskwarrior.org/docs/timewarrior/workweek.html</ref> The documention notes that "Timewarrior focusses on accurately recording time already spent, whereas Taskwarrior looks forward to work that is not yet done."<ref>http://taskwarrior.org/docs/timewarrior/backdated.html</ref>
==Availability== Taskwarrior's source code is freely available and can be compiled and run on a variety of architectures and operating systems, or installed using binaries obtained with common package management tools: ([[Advanced Packaging Tool|apt]], [[Fink]], [[Yellowdog Updater, Modified|yum]], [[DNF (software)|dnf]], pkgng, pkg_add, etc.)<ref>[http://tasktools.org/gitweb/?p=task.git;a=blob;f=NEWS;h=6f87bea2840e2f2f1948125e37a4e1f3091546a4;hb=2.0.0 Task 2.0.0 NEWS file]</ref>
==Typical Workflow== Taskwarrior comprises three main commands: ''add'', ''list'', and ''done.'' All other functionality – recurrences, tags, priorities, etc. – are optional.
===Adding a task=== <source lang="console"> $ task add Pick up keys to the new apartment Created task 1. </source> ===Listing Tasks=== <source lang="console"> $ task list ID Project Pri Due Active Age Description 1 4 secs Pick up keys to the new apartment 1 task </source>
===Marking a task as completed=== <source lang="console"> $ task 1 done Completed 1 'Pick up keys to the new apartment'. Marked 1 task as done. </source> ===Creating a task with due dates, recurrences, and tags=== <source lang="console"> $ task add Mow the lawn project:Lawnwork due:tomorrow recur:biweekly +home Created task 1. </source>
==Syncing== When used in conjunction with Taskserver, can sync tasks into the cloud, and indirectly with other clients/devices.
==Accolades== * Issue 124 of the UK ''[[Linux Format]]'' magazine (November 2009) featured Taskwarrior in its Hot Picks section.<ref>http://www.linuxformat.com/archives?issue=124</ref> * [[RadioTux]] Talk #137 (July 2011, German) chose Taskwarrior as Hot Pick<ref>http://blog.radiotux.de/2011/07/14/talk-137-daumenkino-3-schneller/</ref> * [[FLOSS Weekly]] dedicated episode 175 (July 2011) to Taskwarrior<ref>[http://www.twit.tv/floss175 FLOSS Weekly 175], TWiT.TV</ref> * ''[[Linux Voice]]'' featured a tutorial on Taskwarrior<ref name="LinuxVoice">{{cite journal|last1=Saunders|first1=Mike|title=FOSSpicks: Taskwarrior 2.3.0|journal=Linux Voice|date=September 2014|issue=6|page=69|url=http://www.linuxvoice.com/issues/006/foss6.pdf |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170909053120/http://www.linuxvoice.com/issues/006/foss6.pdf |archivedate=2017-09-09 |deadurl=no}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} {{Use British English|date=October 2017}} {{Infobox business park | name = Thames Valley Park | image = Oracle at Thames Valley Park.jpg | image_upright = 250px | caption = The [[Oracle Corporation]] campus | location = [[Reading, Berkshire|Reading]], [[Berkshire]], [[United Kingdom|UK]] | address = Thames Valley Park
Reading
RG6 1AD | coordinates = {{coord|51.461451|-0.931182|region:GB_dim:3000}} | map_type = United Kingdom Reading | map_caption = Location within Reading | opening_date = | closing_date = | developer = Argent Group | construction_cost = | manager = | owner = | architect = | number_of_tenants = | number_of_workers = | size = | parking = | website = {{URL|thamesvalleypark.co.uk}} | footnotes = }} [[File:Fitness Centre, Thames Valley Park.jpg|thumb|right|250px|[[David Lloyd Leisure|David Lloyd]] Health & Fitness Club.]] '''Thames Valley Park''' is a high-tech [[business park]] adjacent to the [[River Thames]] on the eastern outskirts of [[Reading, Berkshire|Reading]] in the [[England|English]] county of [[Berkshire]]. ==Location and companies== The park partially lies within the [[civil parish]] of [[Sonning]]. Close by are the [[Ali's Pond Local Nature Reserve]], with paths and large ponds, and [[Sonning Hill]]. Companies based at the park include [[BBC Radio Berkshire]], [[Steria]], [[Silicon Graphics|SGI]], [[Regus]], [[BG Group]], [[Websense]], [[Oracle Corporation|Oracle]], [[Microsoft]], [[OpenText]] and [[ING Direct]].{{cite web|title=Companies|url=http://www.thamesvalleypark.co.uk/index.php#bggroup|publisher=Thames Valley Business Park|accessdate=21 April 2012}} ==Transport links== The park is at the northern terminus of the A3290 (formerly part of the [[A329(M) motorway|A329(M)]]) giving good connections to the [[M4 motorway|M4]] and [[A4 road (Great Britain)|A4]]. Originally the A329(M) was supposed to follow the river west from the park towards a junction with Vastern Road.{{cite web|url=http://pathetic.org.uk/current/a329m/maps/a329m-extension.shtml|title=AA map showing A329(M) extension|accessdate=2007-07-17}} There is a [[Zero-fare public transport|free bus service]] between Thames the park and [[Reading railway station]],{{cite web|url=http://www.gogoldline.co.uk/thamesvalleybusinesspark.php4|title=Reading Station and Town Centre to Thames Valley Park|accessdate=2007-07-17|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20040208185051/http://www.gogoldline.co.uk/thamesvalleybusinesspark.php4|archivedate=8 February 2004|df=dmy-all}} with good connections for [[London]] and [[London Heathrow Airport|Heathrow Airport]]. A railway station to serve the park was proposed in the 1998 [[Reading, Berkshire|Reading Borough]] Local Plan,http://ww2.reading.gov.uk/documents/servingyou/planning/borough_plan/bp_appendix8.pdf{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} on the site of the [[coal]] [[Siding (rail)|sidings]] of the closed [[Earley]] [[power station]]. As at April 2013, the station had not been built. ==The Development== The project was commenced by Speyhawk who went into receivership in 1993. Argent Group acquired the site and went on to complete the development in phases. It is built on well over a million cubic metres of pulverised fuel ash, from the power station, to bury the ash, gravels were extracted, and used for the construction of the A329(M) extension, this funded a large part of both the Reading Cross Town Route (A329(M) ) (Thames valley Park Drive) and TVP development. The works were under two separate contracts, completed by Fairclough Civil Engineering - Egham Office. There is a deep pumping station for the development in the centre of the TVP roundabout installed by Trant Contractors. Access is through a tunnel under the Paddington to Exeter railway line from Sutton Seeds Roundabout, dig using the driven shoe method, then precast tunnel sections were installed as linings. The green park is not a natural feature, it was built at the end of the developments, ensuring the flood plain was reinstated and biodiversity improved. Evidence of the old power station is now restricted to a V shaped ditch, running into the Thames near the TVP roundabout to the north west, this was shortened to the point where the outfall of TVP stormwater drainage, and A329(m) drainage meet. Access west into the Reading town, was designed into the roundabout adjacent to the railway line, its levels and layout reflect this, which in some way make its current configuration notable. [[File:Microsoft UK Headquarters, Reading.JPG|thumb|338x338px|Panorama of Microsoft UK Headquarters taken from Microsoft Reception Bus Stop ]] The road was one of the first designed using ground probing radar, which identified some soft ground features prior to commencement of works. [[File:Wiebe Draijer.jpg|thumb|upright|Wiebe Draijer]] '''Wiebe Draijer''' (August 27, 1965) is a [[Netherlands|Dutch]] [[engineer]], and management consultant for [[McKinsey & Company|McKinsey]]. From 2012-2014 he was crown member and chairman of the [[Social-Economic Council]].<ref name="Draijer-CV-SER">{{cite web |url=http://www.ser.nl/nl/raad/raadsleden/kroonleden/draijer.aspx |title=Curriculum Vitae ir. Wiebe Draijer |publisher=[[Social-Economic Council]] |accessdate=19 July 2012|language=nl}}</ref> Since October 2014 he has been Chairman of the Managing Board (CEO) of Rabobank.
== Biography == Born and growing up in [[Enschede]], Draijer wanted to be a [[reporter]], but an uncle advised him to complete a professional study before trying his hand at [[journalism]].<ref name="Draijer-Profiel-VNONCW">{{cite web |url=http://www.vno-ncw.nl/publicaties/Forum/Pages/Profiel_Wiebe_Draijer_de_nieuwe_voorzitter_van_de_SociaalEconomische_Raad_17415.aspx |title=Profiel: Wiebe Draijer, de nieuwe voorzitter van de Sociaal-Economische Raad |publisher=[[VNO-NCW]] |accessdate=19 July 2012|language=nl}}</ref> Following this advise Draijer studied [[mechanical engineering]] at the [[Delft University of Technology]] from 1983 to 1989. During his time as a student he also worked as a [[freelance]] reporter for [[NRC Handelsblad]]. From 1987 to 1989 he completed a traineeship and a year as a researcher at [[Philips Research Laboratories]].<ref name="Draijer-CV-SER"/>
Having completed his university education, he joined McKinsey & Company as a fellow.<ref name="Draijer-Profiel-ED">{{cite web |url=http://www.ed.nl/nieuws/algemeen/economie/11244524/Wiebe-Draijer-nieuwe-SER-voorzitter.ece |title='Wiebe Draijer nieuwe SER-voorzitter' |date=19 June 2012 |work=Eindhovens Dagblad |publisher=ED |accessdate=19 July 2012|language=nl}}</ref> Augmenting his earlier education with an MBA at [[INSEAD]] in Fontainebleau, he was promoted to country managing partner for the Netherlands in 2004 and for the Benelux in 2006.<ref name="Draijer-RTLZ">{{cite web |url=http://www.nuzakelijk.nl/economie/2839161/wiebe-draijer-nieuwe-ser-voorzitter.html |title=Wiebe Draijer nieuwe SER-voorzitter |date=19 June 2012 |work=RTLZ |publisher=RTL |accessdate=19 July 2012|language=nl}}</ref>
During his career at McKinsey, Draijer held several highly visible positions in Dutch society. Among others he was chairman of the [[Stichting_Toekomstbeeld_der_Techniek_(STT)|Stichting Toekomstbeeld der Techniek]] (of which he is still a member of the board), member of the supervisory board of the [[Kröller-Müller Museum]], member of the advisory board for ''Champs on Stage'' (an organization focusing on reducing highschool dropout), member of the advisory board for [[World Press Photo]], member of the Innovatieplatform (a government advisory board to stimulate the Dutch [[knowledge economy]]) and member of the Education Innovation Network. He was also a founding member of 21minuten.nl (now [http://www.denationaledialoog.nl De Nationale Dialoog]), a website focused on generating public debate on political issues as well as more active citizenship.<ref name="Draijer-CV-SER"/>
On 19 June 2012 [[Henk Kamp]] (the Dutch [[Ministry of Social Affairs and Employment (Netherlands)|Minister of Social Affairs]]) nominated Draijer to succeed [[Alexander Rinnooy Kan]] as SER-chairman per 1 September 2012.<ref name="Draijer-CV-SER"/> The SER endorsed this nomination on 21 June 2012 and his appointment became final with [[Queen Beatrix]] signing the appointment in July 2012.<ref name="Draijer-Aankondiging-SER">{{cite web |url=http://www.ser.nl/nl/actueel/persberichten/2010-2019/2012/20120621.aspx |title=SER verheugd met nieuwe voorzitter Wiebe Draijer |date=21 June 2012 |publisher=[[Social-Economic Council]] |accessdate=19 July 2012|language=nl}}</ref>
On 1 July 2014 Draijer left the SER and started to work for [[Rabobank|Rabobank. On 10 September 2014 he was succeeded as chair of the SER by]] [[Mariëtte Hamer]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.parlement.com/id/vjmqj9rzgvfz/nieuws/mariette_hamer_benoemd_tot_nieuwe|title=Mariëtte Hamer benoemd tot nieuwe voorzitter SER|author=|date=29 August 2014|publisher=Parlement.com|accessdate=29 September 2014}}</ref> He was appointed Chairman of the Managing Board of Rabobank on 1 October 2014.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.rabobank.com/nl/press/search/2014/20140509_Indiensttreding_Wiebe_Draijer.html |title=Wiebe Draijer treedt op 1 juli 2014 in dienst van Rabobank |language=Dutch |publisher=Rabobank |date=9 May 2014 |accessdate=29 September 2014}}</ref> He is also a Member of the Board of the Dutch Banking Association, and a Member of the Board of the European Association of Cooperative Banks (EACB).
